My take on the whole giphy being transformative or not case is that gifs of media like shows, movies, videos, and whatever else that isn't also originally intended to be used in the same way as gifs are should count as transformative. No potential consumer in any of the cases above would be lost by them being exposed to it via a few seconds of the movie showing some random scene fitting to the gifs intended theme/application. Might be different for photography, but even then a case could be made for where it was intended to be used and how important it is when compared to the rest of the media it appears in.

It is insane that as Next of Kin in my father's will (since he passed mid-2022), that all the copyrights and revenue for his stories will has passed on to me and then to any children I have in my will, and his work won't become Public Domain at the current rate of Copyright Maximalism until *mid-2092* at the earliest unless I take the time to put them in the PD before they risk becoming an Orphaned Work.

One thing creators could start doing is submitting their works to the public domain after 20 or 50 years (assuming they're still alive). You yourself could just go "yep after 20 years, I'm satisfied with the profit I made, all my old videos are now public domain - have at it." I agree that the law should be changed, but until creators actually start being that change, I fear nothing will happen.

4:21 Is the part "without credit" really true? Copyright is divided into economic rights and moral rights. The latter is about the author's personal connection with the work, for example the right to credit. Moral rights are inalienable and never expire. Of course, the author won't sue you if they're dead, but I think technically you still are obliged to credit them.
The distinction between economic and moral rights varies between countries, but Berne convention, which was signed by most countries of the world, assures that "independent of the author's economic rights, and even after the transfer of the said rights, the author shall have the right to claim authorship of the work".

I would think that there is still something we can do. Have copyright be at 65-70 years (including time when alive), but put limits on how much they can charge. One flat licensing fee for 30-40 years, then after 40 years it should be a flat amount, maybe $500, or $1,000 (up for debate), then lowers as time goes on, until it hits zero when it enters public domain. This way it'll still incentivize corporations to still make money, while allowing some creativity to flourish, as more and more people can afford the licensing fee to license it.

Another important thing I think about the difference between patents and copyright is that patents are described and archived as part of that process, so there isn't the "orphaned works" issue for patent. I honestly think the archival aspect of copyright is something that would be nice to be specifically addressed in law, like adding archival and backup without further distribution until copyright expiration to what is considered a fair use, or having a patent-like system where media must be submitted to a central government database whenever copyright is legally enforced (so if a cease and desist was sent or a lawsuit was brought, to be enforceable, the media would have to be submitted). And then there's the issue of DRM...     anyways, that's all just to say that I think it's really important to not lose even obscure bits of culture and art.

Tom's proposed solution to the problem of excessive copyright duration raises an awkward ethical question. If a musician wrote a song or cut a record in 1970, say, he might - quite reasonably - have thought that this would bring in a handy few shillings for him throughout his life AND do the same for his children. (He probably wouldn't have considered any further down the family tree.) He would have relied upon the law as it stood, which is EXACTLY what we demand of all citizens. It would therefore be grossly unfair to change the copyright duration *retrospectively*, so Tom's 50-yr. rule would only apply to works published after the date of the rule's enactment. Therefore, the rule-change would only start to bear fruit 50 years afterwards, and it would only apply to a small portion of "classic" songs (because I believe that, in fifty years time, we'll still consider the 60s and 70s to be the golden age of pop and rock). It would still be worth doing, mind, as it would pay off eventually, to some extent, but would the punters be satisfied with this outcome, or would they demand retrospective law-changes, regardless of jurists' objections?

At the very least, non-profit use (as long as it doesn't deprive the copyright-holder of profits) should be considered fair use. Licensing the music in a recording to re-issue it is one thing, but then (assuming you believe in I.P. rights at all), using the same photo as the original to sell the re-issue WITHOUT negotiating with the photographer isn't right. But using that photo without selling anything, in a manner that won't deprive the photographer of revenues they'd otherwise have had, should be fair use.

We should abolish the concept of intellectual property (except as it can be cobbled from other property-rights and the right to make contracts and have them enforced against signers AND third parties)."Intellectual property" as it exists now is not a creation of market forces but is entirely a government creation. And the people who say "If we don't have any intellectual property, then the people who create new drugs to cure diseases, and the people who create valuable works of literature, drama, music, and imagery, and the people who invent machines to solve problems, all will receive no compensation for their toil and effort" are simply lying. There ARE other ways, especially in this age of cryptology and crowd-funding. And who thinks that inventors and scientists get compensation for their success anyway? They've signed away their Intellectual Property rights as a condition of being employed. The people who are reaping rewards are stockholders in corporations, not the people who do the work. It's just another scheme whereby the thing that makes entitled to "earn" vast amounts of money boils down to "already having money in excess of your needs". And your "deservingness" is proportion not to your acumen but to the amount of money you already have. Two shrewd investors may work in the exact same manner and employ the exact same diligence and conscientiousness to discover a stock that is going to double in value in six months. One of them has $1,000 to play with, and the other has $2,000 to play with. The latter will "earn" twice as much FOR THE SAME LABOR, DISCIPLINE, and THOROUGHNESS, and it won't be because his input was twice as meritorious. Rather, he's able to back THE SAME input with twice as much money. Who REALLY thinks that the latter investor "earns" twice as much, for the same work? We need to stop rewarding investors (meaning, stop "paying money not to investors but to investors' existing money") and start rewarding creators.

What's worse than copyright law, is patent law. They're both intellectual property and should hold the same terms. 
Both should cease at death of the creator, or until any license agreement at death expires, or 20 years if owned or filed by a company. Current patent laws limit protection to 20 years, even though far more time and money is put into creating an invention than a book or photo. A photo can be created in a fraction of a second, a book in a week, and costs only a few hundred dollars to copyright if you pay someone to do it. A patent takes sometimes decades of work and costs thousands of dollars to get a patent.

Imagine a 20 ~ 50 year copyright period (from date of creation) for a young aspiring musician: they send their demo tracks to one of the big three labels. The lablel rejects it, but simultaneously archives it as a "...maybe later", whilst the songwriter gets zero traction or income from self-publishing efforts because they lack the time, energy, or money to produce and market those tracks themselves.

Years later, one of the big labels pulls that work from a timed archive, transforms it just enough for it to be considered a fresh interpretation on the original, kicking in <their> exclusive copyright term for 20 ~ 50 years.

They make bank. The original songwriter gets nothing.

Now imagine the same scenario for authors, scriptwriters, and all the other artists whose works might never get noticed for <years> until at some point that work resonates with the zeitgeist.

Copyright is, fundamentally, a <human right>, and it exists as a principle of balance between arts, science, and the general public, as found in Article 27 of the United Nations Declaration of Human Rights:

"27.1 Everyone has the right freely to participate in the cultural life of the community, to enjoy the arts and to share in scientific advancement and its benefits.

27.2 Everyone has the right to the protection of the moral and material interests resulting from any scientific, literary or artistic production of which he is the author."

If you reduce copyright in the way this video suggests, you *massively* skew the balance away from creators, to their very great detriment - because although you think it would enrich society as a whole, the entities that would be best placed to benefit from <shorter> copyright durations are the very deep-pocketed monopolies and monopsonies that people accuse of being the beneficiaries of the current system.

That 20 ~50 year (from creation) term wouldn't suck for a tiny minority, but for <millions> of people around the world: the everyday artists trying to scratch out a hobby, a passion, or a side-hustle. Having those artists' work enter the public domain whilst they're still alive only benefits those who are agile enough to exploit it at scale.

Copyright is *your* right, and it is *your* protection against exploitation by corporate megaliths - artists of all kinds just need to learn what it is, what it isn't, and how to make it work for them.

I think there's a compromise in there somewhere. I wouldn't support the reduction of copyright term to anything *less* than the life of the author (I would even say that one ought to be able to leave a "creative will" for what sorts of adaptations are acceptable, but copying and distributing the work becomes legal). Twenty years would allow big corporations to adapt still-popular work without payment. As you state many, many times, anything small creators get legally, corporations also get.

A separate legal provision for copying for nonprofit and archival purposes could also be written into the law, which would probably be more likely to pass than trying to shorten the term.

I have much longer thoughts on "intellectual property" (I dislike the term) reform, but I don't think this is the time or place to delve very deeply into them.

"I'm not convinced we should massively widen the definition of fair use, because every bit of freedom you give to individual creators also makes it easier for big companies to rip them off." This is only true if the law has to treat everyone the same, and it patently doesn't; the law is so riddled with iniquities that it is practically made of them, and I see no reason why we couldn't make one of those iniquities benefit the little guy.

And you touch on a more fundamental point, which I see as: copyright for individual people or small outfits is a band-aid patching over financial insecurity. Your survival should not depend on your stranglehold over your intellectual property, because (a) there should not be strangleholds over ideas and creativity, and (b) human beings are entitled to genuine security, not the caprices of creativity making money. But to give all humans genuine financial security would mean either overhauling the entire system or significantly reforming, neither of which seems likely to happen sadly. I think 50 years is a good term of copyright, at least for the original purposes of copyright as stated, but I could see it be even smaller, as long as individuals could be assured of safety. And the effect on big corporations would be smaller than one might think. If Star Wars were in the public domain now, then how many people would have had the capacity to create the sequel trilogy? Or to create the last four Star Wars video games? Or to distribute them and make all the money they did off them? Not that many people; certainly, not the individual creators who would love the chance to use the Star Wars IP for their own projects. Large corporations have institutional capacities that still mean they could make plenty of money off of public domain IP, it's just that they wouldn't have a stranglehold over it any more.

Good video, but I disagree about the purpose of copyright - or at least what its purpose *should* be. 

Having your song "stolen", is not the same as having your car stolen - you haven't lost your song. The purpose of copyright should be to encourage the production of art. It should be about preserving a *public* good, not about making sure artists can get rich or even  make a living from their art.

To that end, I would be open to getting rid of copyright *completely* if other methods could achieve the same result. Good artists can make some money from supporters on Patreon or similar services while still letting the final product go into the wild for free.  I realize that big budget movies might not be made under these circumstances, but that actually seems like a plus. :)

Couple points:

Copyright's best used is to protect the lil' guy from hungry corporations who look to steal good ideas and profit off them. Why should it work the other way around? Disney, Universal, Big music companies, etc will not go under because some people are using, obtaining, and redistributing their works for free; however the starving artist trying to make a buck to put food on the table will end up homeless if their works are stolen from.

Relating to stock images and footage, if you put your work on the internet and don't expect it to get stolen; that's like going to the marketplace in Madrid with a stuffed wallet in your back pocket and expecting to have that wallet by the end of the day. Don't be ignorant and protect your work like you'd protect your wallet. If they are really worried about losing their work than they shouldn't have online portfolios.

Let's not baby the million and billion dollar companies when they are more than willing to nickle and dime you for everything because of their money-grubbing habits and their overwhelming desire to own the world.

The copyright length, bad as it is, is *exceptionally* ill suited to software (in particular, video games) and its' rapidly changing industry. You end up in a situation where software is "protected" by copyright when it has not been commercially available for decades, is not directly useable on any equipment (or operating system) that's still produced, and more than likely the current owner has no interest in making commercial use of the rights but is more than happy to enforce their ownership. 
The "best" solution there is probably to tie the length not to the date of creation but to the date of last commercial re-release (or sublicensing to a third party for publishing).

I never understood how it was either legal or ethical for copyright extensions to steal from the public (domain) for the benefit of, mostly, corporations far removed from the actual creative work. Each and every one of us is the victim of theft; we are being deprived  of the value we would have derived from that material being free to use, and each day there are new offenses as works that otherwise would have entered the public domain are diverted, the ill-gotten gains of political lobbyists.

It seems to me that any past sale of copyright can now be revisited if the term of rights was stated (or even implied) to be the default term in force at the time. I think it plausible that a creator (especially one motivated less by profit and more by seeking the widest reach) would only accept the restrictions on duplication sold to a publisher as a *temporary, defined* means to that end. For the present rights holder to assert that copyright extension applies alters the thing sold (the rights) beyond recognition and to me that would void the entire contract. I'm speaking of an ideal world, not the illegitimate mess of legislation we are presently burdened with. I'm obviously not a lawyer as I possess common sense and don't want the mess to continue to the benefit of the legal profession (which is simultaneously the oldest profession, the two being essentially the same).

I have a scheme I like to call the "Doubler". You get 5 years of copyright for free. You can extend it for another year past that for $10, the next year for $20, the year after for $40, the year after for $80, then $160 and $320 and $640 and so on and so forth. There is _no cap_ to this: the doubling will go on forever. The corporations who desperately want to keep their cash cows alive will be able to do so, the little people can still extend their copyright to 10ish years for a relatively small fee, and everyone can be happy.

Copyright length should depend on the reasonable investment needed to create the content and the term over which a return on that investment is reasonable. Consider patents, where the term of patent protection is allegedly matched to the time period that a sufficient return on that investment can be made without compromising the creative abilities of others to advance the art and build on prior inventions. It is a balancing act, but the principle is to allow those who invest a day and a small budget on a project a chance to earn proportionate to that art, to allow the one who invested years writing a novel a chance to receive the reward for his sacrifice, and those who spend large sums investing in a production and seeding the arts a chance to reap the reward for their commitment.  I consider it unreasonable to ever allow any art to be copyright protected following the death of the artist. Corporations holding copyrights should have shorter protection tenure than individual holders.  Finally, a lot of content that has copyright claim is a derived work, and that also needs to be addressed, because the effort needed to produce 100% original art is magnitudes harder than reworking, repackaging, re-recording, assembling, or parroting prior art.

Back in the 90s, there was an Australian sketch comedy show called "The Late Show" (No relation to the David Letterman version). Many people rememeber it fondly but it was never released on VHS and DVD (when that became a thing), much to everyone's displeasure. Rather a compilation was the only thing available which baffled many people.

The creators later explained that the live show contained many video clips from news shows, commercials, film reviews etc... but it was all fair use since the network it aired on is government funded and does not allow advertising. This meant that there was no revenue at all generated from the show, apart from absolute hilarity.

If however it they were to release complete episodes on DVD (Which they did plan on), the creators would have to contact EVERY SINGLE featured video creator, of which there were hundreds, making it a legal mess. Hence the compilation only featured clips that contained no licensed or copyrighted material.

Having said that, the episodes are available on Youtube thanks to people with better VCRs than mine. And they used SP recording...

This is a well made video. Very informative and gives insight to the copyright systems mentioned. I don't think it is a problem with the dmca system that people should complain about, but rather the people that abuse it. There are numerous companies and individuals that use it to either silence, troll, or even scam content creators. There are channels I have watched that are constantly fighting strikes and copyright claims on videos that involve police officers and their vest or dash cams because either the system YouTube uses to detect them thinks it's an episode of Cops or because some lawyer that's all the video thinks it's an episode. I have also seen instances where mysterious companies would pop up and claim a bunch of random videos and start collecting ad revenue from them. But as soon as somebody starts investigating to figure out who they are, they just disappear. You are right, this is not a problem with YouTube's copyright system. It's running as good as it can as it is. The problem is people. With any luck, the laws and systems in place now will be improved soon. But even if they end up becoming absolutely perfect, there will still be complaints. The thing about people is even when compromising, neither party really agrees with the arrangement. One wants more than the other in most cases. And there will always be those that try to exploit any system to get what they want at any cost
As bad as companies promising new artists photographers and music "exposure" in return for an unlimited usage license for eternity with no fees or royalties due.

To answer the question of "fair use", simply ask yourself whether your usage will lose the Copyright owner revenue (cause financial damage). If your use does lose the owner money, then you've almost certainly broken Copyright law.

This isn't about your making money from someone else's Copyright material, it's about whether your earnings are money that should rightly have come to the Copyright owner. 

The key question is whether your use is affecting the revenues of the Copyright owner.

The court rulings "although sparce" DO allow for a lot of the stuff you claimed was illegal. You even showed the H3 case, but kind of skipped over the more detailed breakdown of why it was legal. The weight of each of the categories is not even, and those categories are all that matters. Most importantly are monetary effect and market replacement. For example: H3 pauses the video every few seconds, providing commentary which is frequently nothing more than jokes. The way you described it simply making jokes "is not criticism and review" but that's exactly the way H3 argued their case, the jokes count as criticism and the work counted as transformative. The original clip being played is not replaced by the reaction video because the point of the original video is sufficiently disrupted by the reaction, so you don't get the same experience watching the original video as watching the reaction video.

It takes a lifetime of training and dedication to became a songwriter or musician. One-hit wonders don't happen by accident usually. They happen because one person spent his life writing song after song after song and just by chance one of them got recorded and made a hit. That's not just a few hundred people. That's the vast majority of the music business. It takes thousands of people churning away making failed songs for society as a whole to benefit from the froth that all that churning creates for the really good stuff to be made. If you don't let one hit wonders and failed songwriters have a chance at making a decent living on what they spend their lives doing, then they won't engage in all that churn, and the level of froth will drop. Quality will drop, variety will drop, innovation will come slower. When creativity becomes something only hobbyists with another source of income can do, rather than a possible profession, then we will all suffer as a society. I say, yes, shorten the copyright term, but no shorter than the lifetime of the original creator.

Honestly I think the solution is great, and to creators, a general rule of thumb is "what if it was a picture/video/orchestration from Disney?" That will generally get people to second guess using content outside of their content. Obviously not perfect, what with confusion as to what's transformative and people wrongly using others hard work for free and what qualifies as an art piece that falls under copyright, but a good start.

Also, I believe there needs to be a good faith argument for allowing penalty free take downs so owners can keep their copyright and users can safely use it and remove it if there is accidental/unintentional infringement so companies can't sue individuals or platforms out of existence just for a 5 second moment in the video where the company owned song was in the background. Not entirely sure what the legal ramifications of this is (not a lawyer) but many small creators, in my opinion, don't intend to infringe copyright because they don't have/can't afford legal counsel nor can they afford the settlement offers of "give us all your money from that video or we'll sue."

i think that they should have a number of credits effectively that it costs to content claim something
if their claim was valid and appropriate they get the credit refunded
if it was not and they were effectively abusing the system aiming for free money they don't
if they run out of credits they are able to pay for more with each one costing more than the last
and have the credits reset every year or some other pre defined period

though the issue with this is that it would require youtube's existing system to be executed at it is intended to be not just rushed through by the lowest bidder for easy money

i also think the same system should be used for disputing claims on a content creators content

i am sure there are other issues with this exact concept but at a baseline it seems like it would encourage a lot more fair use from both parties

The problem is that humans.have a natural urge to be selfishly greedy, which is why there exists ownership of resources‚Äîproperty. Given the existential risk involved in physically fighting each other to acquire ownership of a resource, we have come to impose upon ourselves the "civil" alternative we call "trade". This necessarily imposes upon ourselves some kind of set of governing rules, to wit, an economic system, which necessarily puts price stickers on everything. Since we each have only a finite amount of resources (such as money) with which to trade at any given time, an economic system is a rationing system, allocating resources according to some or other criterion. (Capitalism, for example, allocates resources fundamentally according to the individual's innate ability to acquire them, which is unfair given that innate ability is unchosen, unalterable and personally unique, resulting in inequality of personal outcomes. Capitalism is also inefficient; for example, rival pharmacological companies not sharing commercially sensitive research‚Äîhiding research-discovery pieces of the same treatment jigsaw from each other‚Äîresulting in unnecessary duplication of effort and precluding the efficiency which is the building upon each other's research and discoveries. "USSR communist-type" economies stifle endeavour as the people are allocated resources equally no matter what any individual's productive output. *All* economic systems are unfair and inefficient, stifling progress, by definition.) We don't need economic systems‚Äîthey're not like gravity. Let's abandon them.

I'm a little confused by some of this. How could a "Let's Play" or streaming yourself playing a video game not be considered transformative? Perhaps I'm a bit thick, but it seems like the literal definition of transformative as you're transforming a video game into a video. I mean, if I published a game containing assets they had a copyright to, sure sue me, but the copyright holder is presumably in the business of producing and selling video games and not videos of people playing video games, right?

I realize this is all case law based and there is no way to definitively determine something that hasn't had a related case go all the way through the courts, but as a thought experiment: if I were to write a computer program that created abstract images by using sound waves as an input, could a music company sue me for creating and selling images based on their copyrighted music?

After watching the video, I agree with 90% of this, as creator I disagree with 10% of this, see the activity of a copyright should come into play and not plagiarize the original work either. Whatever enters PD should still respect the original work. Say your 50yr/20yr plan comes into play, and your copyright is a active intellectual property, such as is interacted with on a daily basis by a large audience or is used as a consistent means of income to a party, how are you specifically accommodating the creator/ self employment stability of that creator. I can understand static works that have no financial repercussions as in the author has no desire to profit from it. 

But put yourself in the eyes of craftsmen/ tradesmen/ artisans and artists, etc; that hone there skill religiously for years to have their vision completely ripped from them because the public is throwing a tantrum because you have been playing toooo long with a specific toy you made, it's comparable to having your house ripped from beneath your feet because you stayed there too long and it's someone else's turn, but you "own" it as in it is "yours". Copyright is there to protect the owner, so therefore that waver on a 20 year policy you proposed defeats the purpose of copyright itself. It should remain a lifetime affair, if it becomes a recognizable brand it should remain a copyright in next of kin or party of kin up until they decide it to be PD.

Or better yet place yourself in a position where your videos lose revenue because they have entered public domain..... but whine about the "private media outlet" despite it being a private institution that broadcasts media and profits, then pays employees who have livelihoods too and belong to the public, do you think you're suddenly not going to want your IP? You filed a case against this entity?  seriously it's hypocritical to just think about it. Transformative content should be redefined not copyright

Who can forget the big Kerbal Space Program Purge a few years ago?

The game used music licenced by Kevin MacLeod. The music is technically royalty free, but they got a licence from him anyway.
One piece was later used by a musician since it is royalty free. This particular piece was playing when a player got their rocket just past the barrier between atmosphere and space. A fairly common occurrence for players in a game about rockets and space exploration.

This musician added some windchimes on top of the existing track and uploaded it to YouTube, as-is, as their own creation. This was allowed, according to the licence.
This musician then had a rights management company take care of this piece of music, and they added the song in its entirety to the Content ID library.

What followed was a couple of hundreds of thousands of Let's Play videos instantly being flagged for copyright infringement. Back when YouTube had a 3-strike rule that applied to Content ID matches as well.
A LOT of people lost their channels that day. A lot never regained them, even after this whole ordeal was sorted out.
A lot of those who did never returned to YouTube.

This, for me, was the single biggest display of how skewed the system is. This system which apparently isn't broken. The one so non-broken that the in-stream advert for the video telling us how not broken it is, is for a rival service where the same content creator has started putting their content.

here is the thing: If i upload a crappy starwars battlefront 2 let's play (don't worry, the old one, not the new one) and i get a claim for a 12 second segment of music in a cutscene that is part of the game then I would be happy to share the generated revenue for that 12 second part, no problem!
But here is where the problem starts: this 12 second segment is part of a video with a total length of over 20 minutes, that's less than 1% of the entire video. I spent a lot of time into recording, editing and rendering. Now i put about 4h work into this one video and all revenue generated, the result of those 4 hours of work get taken away from me for 1% of the video that is overlayed with heavy sounds of gunfire. I don't say I own 100% of the video, they own that 1% as it was a cutscene and it wasn't transformative, so I would be willing to give them a small ammount of the revenue, but not 100%.
Yet those 12 seconds of music, those 0.something% of copyrightet music mean that they own 100% of the 20+ minutes video that I spent 4h recording, editing and rendering.

The Kind of Bloop case was so ridiculous. 
Firstly, it wasn't ran through a pixelation filter, it was drawn, and I imagine it took a considerable amount of time to make and used artistic skills very different to what the photographer used to take the photo.  It was a piece of art, in its own right, that was based upon the look of Miles Davis.
There are hundreds of images and videos of Miles Davis showing him at so many different angles.  Does that mean if someone draws an image of Miles Davis from memory or imagination at an angle that happens be the same angle as one of the photos or videos, they are infringing copyright?  Andy Baio did admit that the drawing was based upon the photo but that's not relevant when you consider that the end result is two separate works of art showing Miles Davis at the same angle.

 A photographer owns the photo, not the angle.

If someone takes a photo of Joe Biden at a press conference and another photographer moves into that spot and ends up taking a photo that looks almost exactly alike, who is infringing who's copyright when they go to sell their photos?

You see how ridiculous things get when copyright laws are followed to the nth degree.
Copyright "should" be for theft, not for making money without working !

I got a claim on one of my songs, but the song the copyright owner said I used doesn‚Äôt seem to exist online, and the claiming company doesn‚Äôt have any online presence. Furthermore I used two Splice samples I purchased the rights to. The samples are licensed non-exclusively meaning I can‚Äôt submit my derivative work to the Content ID database, but that also means that other derivative works can‚Äôt claim ownership of the sample used in my track. They rejected my dispute of the claim and I‚Äôm now in the appeal stage waiting for their response. 

I don‚Äôt reject the copyright system because its how I make money from music, but I wish the process wasn‚Äôt so hands-off and unregulated. I‚Äôm confident that once my claim reaches an objective third party then the claim will be dropped, but it seems that if Content ID makes a mistake or if someone gets ineligible work into the Content ID database, then anyone can file a fraudulent claim if given the opportunity by a misfire of the ID algorithm, and a third party doesn‚Äôt get involved until after you appeal a takedown order after months of disputes and appeals. And I‚Äôm not talking about fair-use like reviews or background music, I don‚Äôt do that content and don‚Äôt care, its about musical works, source material and third party moderation of claims.
I believe cover versions require mechanical licenses, not sync licenses. Sync licenses are for using copyrighted recordings/masters in a soundtrack.

A question raised by this that I'm never sure about is how the law determines what constitutes a lost sale.  Is the assumption that anyone who watches a YouTube video of someone playing a video game is a potential paying consumer of that video game?  I can see why it might be, but I would argue that it's unlikely that that is actually the case.  If I watch 100 videos of gameplay from different games today, am I meaningfully depriving 100 game companies of potential revenue... given that there's no way I was going to buy 100 games in one day?

The conceit seems to be that anyone who gets your product for free is a potential paying customer.  But businesses use loss-leaders as an enticement to buy other products all the time.  So I'd argue that it's not that simple.

Interestingly, copyright in America was originally just for 28 years, with a one-off option to renew for a further 28 years - in effect, copyright lasted for 56 years and not one second longer. This was plenty of time for a creator to make as much money as they could reasonably expect off a given work. But Disney kept lobbying to extend that, to the point that it now lasts 70 years longer than the creator themselves.

One thing I'd add to Scott's solution is that if all holders of copyright on a given work die, it immediately enters public domain.

For as long as a party can claim an *entire video and all its revenue* because they own a small (or substantially altered) portion of it, I outright refuse to let it stand as an acceptable affair, even in the light of the world's *entirely* broken, due-for-almost-complete-replacement copyright system.
Also, yes, fair use should be *massively* expanded for non-commercial use, and any sort of compensation or penal action on the side of the defendant should be void. Cease-and-desist should be the maximum damage that can be incurred.

Non-commercial derivative works with substantial alterations should simply be fair use, and something like Youtube's content-ID system certifying the substantial alteration should be enough to close the case in favour of the defendant, or at least shift the burden of proof.

On a wider note, the system is broken in more ways: People shouldn't need to worry about making a living. If capitalism can't provide free housing, for example, capitalism is a failure that needs to be abolished. I believe it can provide free housing, so I think capitalism doesn't need to be abolished.

 To me, the way a system works out for the bottom 10% of society is categorical to my judgement of it. If it fails in that regard, the system gets an F.

I disagree with shortening the copyright length. In fact, I think it should be extended. HOWEVER I think there should be a split depending on who holds the copyright - private individuals (author and descendants) and corporations.
I'd extend copyright to 100 years for private individuals. So the author enjoys it unto his death and so would his children and grandchildren who would have had contact with the author and to whom the works are also part of the memories from their parent or grandparent.
However, if the copyright is owned by a corporation, that time would get reduced to, at most, 50 years. Because there's no sentimental value involved there and a corporation is more able to monetise the sh*t out of the content before the copyright expires than individuals are.

I have what older people would consider a dangerously radical position. There shouldn't be copyright at all. Not in the current sense. Instead, there should be citation law. That is, you can reuse any work you want, but you have to credit the original in a manner consistent with the prominence of your use of it. The result is that people will pay the creator roughly proportional to how much they think the creator deserves, rather than how much the creator wants to charge.

While much of this video is great, it misses the reality for small creators of the AUTOMATED systems.  They often pick up uses that NO human would challenge - thus creating unfair claims.  For example, I had a video of an RC helicopter flight copyright struck due to a reflection of a tv-show being played in a window that was visible for just a handful of frames with no audio.  It was hardly visible, and certainly unrelated to the video - and nothing a HUMAN lawyer nor viewer would have noticed.  I don't make a career on YouTube, and it is an unacceptable grab for systems like these.  If we are going to be judged by AI systems there must be more transparency, more content creator control, and the ability to challenge claims fairly and test with these same tools.  Not all impacted videos are 'reaction videos' or other potentially actually copyright-infringing videos.

One important keyword is "commercially," so none of this applies to memes made and shared among a private group (say in a chat) for purely comedic purposes. Moreover, if anything like this did become an issue, the violation of privacy by exposing a chat's messages would be far worse than the violation of copyright.

In the current culture around referencing, the idea of short clips used as a punch line should be accepted. Memes and gifs are other examples where the line in the movie or a still image of a scene can convey a feeling that applies to a different situation for a comedic effect. And that SHOULD BE ALLOWED. Again, this restriction stifles creativity and prevents people from actively enjoying media.

Part of the solution could be some kind of brokerage that licenses music and can deal in licenses for a minor fee, so it's not prohibitive to smaller creators, who aren't the enormous companies the system was designed for. The point being licenses shouldn't be too expensive, and their current price stifles creativity.

Another more recent note, CGP Grey used someone's music WITH a license and it still got claimed. How is the system supposed to verify legitimate licenses, or is it not trying to do that at all anyways?

I think the "declared value copyright" system would be a much better solution to replace the current system. The idea is as follows: you get 2 (two) year copyright with similar terms as today and you can extend the copyright for as long as you want for a registration fee. The registration fee is 1% of the declared value of the works per year. Anybody who pays copyright owner the declared value *frees* the work to public domain. The list of registered works and the declared values of each work are public.

Example: Disney creates the New Lion King movie. They get 2 year copyright for free. If they want a longer copyright protection they have to decide a price tag for the works. Let's say they decide "900 million dollars". That means that they have to pay 9 million dollars to the society to extend the copyright for an another year. And if many enough fans want to free the New Lion King, they can create growdfunding project to collect 900 million dollars to pay Disney and release that movie to public domain.

The fee part makes sure that copyright owner will not adjust the price too high. And the ability to release the work makes sure that works can enter public domain if the declared value is priced too low to avoid fees.

It also makes much easier to *check* if any given work is public domain. If any given work is older than 2 years and it has not been registered, it's public domain. And once you create something, you have 2 years to decide if you think *you* can monetize it in the future. And you can always get an extra year by paying 1% of the any value you want to specify. Just remember that if you declare that your work is worth $1, *anybody* can turn it to public domain by paying you that sum.

I'd argue that the real petulant children whining about nonsense are the people and corporations who demand to receive compensation for work they didn't do (Disney, Marvel, and, yes, even most youtubers). Take your photographer example, that photographer performed labor to create the picture and should be compensated for ONLY that labor. If the distribution of that photo requires more labor, than the people who distribute the photo should get paid for that labor. 
No other worker gets paid for work that they might have done 70 years ago, why are novelists and painters at all different. If a plumber fixes my toilet, I don't then pay them for the right to use it. Furthermore, in order to get paid for work you don't do, someone must go without payment for work they did do. 
Intellectual property is private property and therefore exploitative. It should be abolished.

I think the problem is that the way that the copyright law works (assuming that it does) is similar to the figure skating judges in the Olympics.  Meaning very very few people compared to the number who actually see it understand how it functions which means it is opened to abuse deliberate or otherwise.  That everything exists in a gray area is why this set of laws is (or just feels) broken.  If I speed I as a layman can understand the law, how I broke it and even have a reasonable understanding of what penalties I will have.  Copyright is nothing like that, it is inherently designed so that laypeople can not understand it and the penalties can vary from a warning to astronomical fines and even possible jail time if those fines aren't paid or can't be paid.  The fact that this can is being kicked further and further down the road even though Generation X, Y, Z and beyond have been on the internet most of their life is just wrong!  That we allow this to be treated as new technology is just wrong, and is broken.  If image hosting sites and video streaming services have to defend their existence to make these laws more reasonable and understandable then we should push for that.  That Spotify pays for the music on their service but YouTube pretends it is a problem that is too large and too complex is just wrong.

Copyright was originally designed to be a compromise: the government saw benefit in protecting people's right to profit off their own work, but it also saw that it needed to protect the right of the public to eventually use preceding work freely, because letting companies hold intellectual property forever stifles creativity. The public domain was an integral part of the compromise. But companies have lobbied to continually change copyright law so that their big moneymakers will never enter the public domain. The implications of all that has been manifest through  terms and definitions of legality may be one of the messiest issues facing humanity.  The extent of that which can be owned by some who have benefited the most from these definitions is staggering. In essence, it is not unreasonable to say that all speech, nay even lives, could through legality be denied because of perceiving these definitions as societal law.  Definitions that in part evolved through precedent that a greater majority do not understand,  and in lack of understanding were susceptible to great loss.  Definitions that outside the provable realm of ownership of individual creative process was the claim by legal writ to things like the bulk of natural resource in major regions of the globe. Claim, that left the inhabitants of those areas without resource and by degree dependent on those who layed legal claim to said resource  To participate as an individual in making yourself dependent on these definitions is the surest legal guarantee to have no voice in relation to them.  That which is dependent is governed by the thing it is dependent upon.  The one thing I am most thankful for everyday is not having my individual benefit tied to these fractal definitions of what is owned. In this, like the majority that I am part of, I own nothing by these definitions. In owning nothing, is not being susceptible to having what is not owned claimed by legal definition.  I am not the example for others in these ways. If anyone wishes to come to a different understanding of their own lives through different process than what  has been established through precedent merely accept the burden that is not the guarantee of individual benefit.  Carrying any burden/weight is an act that allows us to come an understanding based upon the burden accepted. Most chose the burden that they believed to be for their benefit.  Different burden accepted is different understanding. All understanding in relation to burdens carried is needed in our collective advancement. Tell your story. if it is outside the norm of these legal definitions, for it is just as important as what the "norm is defining as important.

While I agree the copyright system isn't perfect and there is room for reform, I don't think I agree with the extent to which you are proposing to shorten the duration of copyright. As you mentioned, copyright law is intended to prevent others from profiting from the creativity of artists and authors, I do not believe that any term less than the natural life of the artist or author would be sufficient. I think creators should be entitled to defend their creative works from unlawful exploitation until the end of the year in which they die. Your argument that extended duration of copyright stifles creation baffles me - copyright stimulates creation by allowing creators of *original* (emphasis added) works to profit from their work. If the work is not original, then it would not meet the criteria for copyright, so I'm not sure how a reduced duration of copyright would benefit creators. I think the comparison with the duration of patents is flawed - the innovations and inventions protected by patents are, by and large, for public benefit and the advancement of society as a whole. I don't think the same argument can be made for creative works.

The second point I wish to make is in relation to fair dealing vs fair use.  In the UK (and in Australia where most of our laws are based on UK laws), acts that constitute fair dealing is defined in legislation, so there is less room to argue what kind of use constitutes "fair dealing", and is far less ambiguous than the "fair use" system favoured in the US. I particularly enjoyed the last portion of the video in which you spoke about the intellectual property court in the UK, and how a similar but flawed system is being proposed in the US. I think on the whole, the UK has a better copyright system overall.

There's one way in which YouTube's copyright system IS broken and DOES NOT NEED TO BE.

Let's say someone levels a copyright strike against your video.  You're convinced the claimant is wrong, and that your video doesn't violate copyright.  You provide your full legal contact information so the claimant can sue you directly, and file a counter-claim with YouTube.

Under America's DMCA, YouTube has the right to say "Okay, we're putting your video back up unless the claimant can prove he's taking legal action against you.  According to the DMCA's Safe Haven laws, so long as we provide your legal information to the claimant, YouTube can no longer be sued over your video.  We wash our hands of you."

But that's NOT WHAT YOUTUBE DOES.  Instead, they REVIEW your counter-claim and DECIDE FOR THEMSELVES whether THEY think you violated copyright or not.  There is no lawyer involved, certainly no judge, just a quick bureaucratic yes-or-no decision.  If some yahoo who got assigned to answer the counter-claims today thinks you violated copypright because his bowels are acting up, YouTube will REJECT YOUR COUNTER-CLAIM and keep your video disabled (and keep the copyright strike against you).

Most people fundamentally misunderstand the purpose of Youtube's copyright system.  Youtube are not in the business of making judgments and ruling on disputes.  Youtube merely provide the mechanisms to process the copyright claims, facilitate takedowns and an appeals process that puts the two parties in touch with each other.  They expect content creators and copyright claimants to sort out disputes between themselves, employing legal means if need be.

Youtube takedown content when requested in order to avoid legal liability and will not rule on disputes for the same reason.

Hrm. Speaking of MST3k.... at the end of their stuff, for many years, was an ack that one reason why they got famous was people sharing videos of their stuff well outside their original market -- "Keep sharing the tapes". This is probably one of the most glaring examples of the benefits of piracy under the correct circumstances. Most people would never have even heard of MST3k if it had been stuck in its own little UHF Minneapolis market...

In other words, their performances are nominally public domain, they've relinquished their own copyright over them.

But you could probably still shut that down if you wanted, by invoking the "It's A Wonderful Life" trick. 

As you are likely aware, the studios screwed up, and allowed the copyright for "It's A Wonderful Life" to lapse, meaning that it fell into the public domain, and any network could play it for free. And so, for about a decade it got played... and played.... and played.... anywhere near Xmas -- it was free advertising money for the stations that aired it... and anytime they had nothing better to put on, "Boom, there it is!"

Then some Bright Boy lawyer registered a copyright on the soundtrack (or perhaps a synchronization license? Dunno)... and, while you could play it as a silent movie, you now can't play it with the audio track...

In a possibly similar thing, while MST3k itself is likely in the public domain, and legal to distribute (though not assessed as such by the courts, it seems improbable that "Keep circulating the tapes" would not be adjudicated as a mostly complete release of all rights, certainly for non-commercial distribution) -- while MST3k had licensed the original movies for their own performances, that doesn't mean they were necessarily licensed for repeated performances, which yet another Bright Boy lawyer could use to gain control over their distribution and performance.

As far as games are concerned, it's actually fairly simple: Studios that produce genuinely **good** games have a lot to gain from massive exposure to their target audiences via popular streamers and Youtubers. The increase in sales for them is substantial, that's why some of them not only encourage people to stream/upload footage of their games, but even pay the bigger channels for it, sponsoring X hours of gameplay (knowing full well that most will continue streaming even after the paid part is over). 

On the other hand, studios and publishers that produce Spunkgargleweewee (the better part of the 'AAA'-industry) probably are better off avoiding exposure like that, at least prior to and immediately after the launch of a title. They instead love to impose embargos for the sole reason of keeping their pre-order sheep and other hype victims as un-informed as possible about the boatload of crap they're going to deliver.

This is where our governments and The Law completely fails us. When creating a law that is suppose to have final say over what is legal and what isnt, especially when it comes to something as simple as using a video or a piece of music, there should be NO grey area. It should be cut and dry simple. Having those grey areas is what allows big corporations to effectively screw over the little guy, even if they did NOTHING wrong all because they can't afford to pay the legal fees in order to defend themselves.  They have effectively locked people's ability to defend themselves behind a Pay wall. So it doesn't matter if your 100% in the right, did everything the correct way and the corporation that is sueing you is just being greedy bastards trying to literally STEAL your money.  If you can't afford to fight it in court, at best you just have to  remove the content you depend on for money and at worst you end up paying out a lot of money to a corporation that legally doesn't deserve it. The current copyright laws have made a modern day version of highway robbery a VERY easy thing to do and for large companies a lot of the times a VERY lucrative business practice that some businesses are completely centered around. This end up leaving smaller individual content creators with no way of defending themselves.  So regardless if this is how it is, it NEEDS to change. Governments around the world are not changing with the times. They can no longer afford to let laws sit around unchanged for 10 years, let alone for 50 or 100 years like they use to. Technology and our society are moving forward at a break neck speed, and the law needs to keep up or risk becoming obsolete or even creating worse problems then they were created to fix.

What determines whether or not a cover is done for a particular song? 

Is it the title? Well, I can make it more vague or encrypted.

Is it the chords I used? Chords don‚Äôt belong to anyone, and if they did, music companies would be suing each other relentlessly because so many songs use the same chords and in the same order (ex: Ed Sheeran lawsuit).

Is it the melody? I can adjust it and add a little improvisation or keep the chorus melody but change the melody of the verses or maybe do one of a million things that can make my cover just slightly different from the original.

The point I‚Äôm trying to make is that there is no clear distinction between copyrighted work and my own work. It would be much simpler if everything published online would be public domain, which would also solve piracy and censorship to a degree.

small uni theatre person here. we don't have money to buy licenses for anything. We have to for a huge majority of the time rely on works in public domain. We do a bunch of shakespeare, because you can go absolutely wild on it with no copyright. Actually, probably some of the most creative things we've done were with shakespeare. I just had an absolute moment of HORROR when I imagined we'd have to pay on that. Or were absolutely fixed and forced to remain 100% true to one version. No. that WOULD be the end of us. 
And second, shorter terms for that would be brilliant. Do you know how often we have conversations complaining about people's death dates because they died less than 70 years ago? How we sit there dammit, couldn't they have died earlier--because no, we don't want them to have died earlier. we'd just love to interpret their works. We recently celebrated that GB Shaw is just above 70 years dead this month because we can now use his works. 
I don't really have a conclusion for this. Just a small rant from a theatre person, because in this aspect I often encounter that. And because I just had a moment of utopic happy dreaminess when I imagined what many awesome works we could stage and bring to people if the copyright were shorter, if it were 20 or even the 50 years. That would be incredible.

Tom: A neglected aspect of IP.  Taxpayers fund the government departments that protect the social contract of IP.  The other side of that deal is that at the end of some time the works taxpayers are paying to protect will become public property for their use.   The value of government protection is very, very high.  How high?  Financial test: if IP owners had to pay 100% of the cost of defending their IP, would they make profits?  (Answer: no).   In a fair system, those who fund IP protection would set the amount of time they were willing to pay before they received benefit.  So yes, the world's IP system is corrupt because the people funding it clearly have no voice in making the deal.

We can essentially just keep rolling the dice with Content ID and such, or be prepared to walk away from it all. Sucks, but until both copyright isn't as long term and fair use is a more accessible defense, the copyright owners hold all the cards and power.

Is it just me, or is this problem getting worse?

MuseScore was originally meant to be an online community where people could share sheet music with one another, and there was a premium option that gave you a few boosts. It was the place to go if you wanted free sheet music. And there were titles on there that technically *didn't* constitute fair use, but also other parodies too, since it was a community.

Everything was fine. No one did anything, it was a community. Everyone understood, it was "widely understood" as you put it that people did not have malign intentions in publishing this music.

A few months back MuseScore announced that because they couldn't possibly pay royalties to authors with only ads, they had to make almost every feature you could do with a work by an author (like downloading, etc.) paid.

Fast forward to now -- 90% of the content originally on the platform, 99% of all "major song" titles are gone, copyright-striked by companies like Kobalt. All that's really left on this (IMO) once great, but now paid platform is a few custom creations and stuff that's left in the public free-to-use domain. However, they still do provide a good tool for creating your own content.

Again, this might just be my own opinion, but it seems like (especially large) corporations are now bearing down on copyright more than they ever have before...

And as for 'short-term' fixes that would help more imho than the constant flow of bandaid fixes copyright anddmca have seen, it should be a thing that frequent bad-faith/fasle dmca claimsneed to result in reduced chances of such cases from that individual or company being successful, like the entire copyright troll legal issue that there isno harsh penalty for dmca abuse. Imho if a case for a dmca claim doesmakeitto court, there should also be a genuine risk for the claimant should they be proven it is either a flat-out false claim, bad faith OR that they struck down blatant fair use (such as musical composition analasys and explanation) rather than the current iteration wherethe big recordlabelshave nothing to lose with their dmca abuse.
As a small scale author,i do agree that shortening copyright is reasonable, if done to a sensible degree, and 'till death+ 70 years' for individual creators is insane and realistically too long. But the soleprotection of copyright law and dmca should not be for the copyright holder. If i were to strike down amy and all content that discusses my writing in a fair use way, clearly being analasys and criticism, i SHOULD LOSE the right to strike and have no risk on my end. Current law does favor the copyright holder in every way, which inmany is good,but the ability to throw rampant floodsof unlawful claims needs to have risks associated beyond the 'if they can bring it to court we should drop the claim cuz expensive' to the point that it would be better to provide amneties that should copyrught claims on fair use or in blatant bad faith come from a single entity, there need to be waysto cause them reprcussions regardless if they drop the claim, and that should include low-cost starting options for the person being struck and mandatory for the copyright claimant to attend while that court does also have the right to enforce the decision (much like the U.K. version) 
In short, while the copyright holders should not have their protection lessened,there needto be enacted harsh repercussions dor unlawful claims that ANY individual could recognize as fair use to prevent dmcaabuse as it happensnowadays and that means a need to uodate and entirwly rework copyright law in a way that makes sense for the current era. And perhaps include madatory reassesments of needed reworks every 'insert reasonable amount of years'

I think copyright should kind of be based on how much you're making out of that content, if you're a big company like Disney, putting content in a film that will earn millions, then in that case the laws should be strict. If you're just a kid, or individual who doesn't make any or little money of their videos then copyright laws should be just a bit more forgivable.  And of course the laws should be varying for the varying amount of money that you're making. So if you earn a bit of money, you don't get let off as easily as someone who doesn't earn anything, but also aren't treated as a multi million dollar corporate entity. Of course these boundaries (a lot, a little, a bit) would be defined by law. And this kind of thing would also be able to include what Tom mentioned, where there is a small claims court, for those that use content unfairly, or for those that do use it, but are misunderstood.

The key here should be less legislation and restriction, reduce time before works move to public domain, and those with small audiences like community theaters and small youtube creators should be able to use what they want in the name of creativity. If they start making serious money on something, then that is a different discussion. Individuals who own copyright on their own creative works should get all their copyright revenue, but huge mega corps with CEOs earning 8 and 9 figure salaries who own an astronomical amount of copyrights they had no creative hand in actually making, and have draconian exploitative contracts with the actual creators of the content should have their cut heavily taxed, with the revenue from that tax going to national and local art and creative initiatives. Individuals should get paid for their work, huge companies whose entire purpose is to make money from someone else's work (and are the real copyright 'infringers' for that reason) should not. And that is what is truly infuriating about this whole situation. It isn't a problem that people want to make money from their work, it is that the only people who are actually benefiting from the current system are huge companies with tons of money and lots of lawyers, and not the people who actually contribute to the furthering of art, culture, and creative endeavors.

Great video Tom! After living in the african nation of Zambia for some time, I discovered that they are less focused on civil law and more focused on common law. When you talk about the "widespread understanding" it reflects the legal theory of the "reasonable person test." Essentially, what would a reasonable person understand about the issue at hand? Zambia focuses on common law more and civil law only practically takes precedence on high profile cases. Common law is more widely used in their local courts and I believe this is both a good and bad thing. As you've discussed in your video most civil laws take decades to catch up with the norm, or what society dictates. If the court focuses on common law their decisions don't have to be fully dictated by what the civil law states, that way they can be flexible as social understandings change. The downside to this is that common can be heavily variable, changing from day to day. This makes it difficult to predict if an action will be considered legal/acceptable or illegal/unacceptable. The slow civil law makes it easier to predict if an action would be considered unfair. I do think that big companies abuse these systems because they want every single penny of profit, and in some cases it's justified but others it is straight up unfair. Until civil law can update and be as flexible as common law, common law should be recognized with equal consideration as the civil law. This is issue is a very difficult one and I'm glad you created such a funny and informative video!

I really appreciate this video. I've learned a lot watching this, although it has not necessarily changed any opinions I have. I would still consider Youtube's copyright systems to be broken: if we take your duct tape metaphor and extend it a bit, Youtube's systems are strip of duct tape that have been holding together something for much longer than it should have been; old crusty, and likely to crumble if more pressure is applied from the inside.

In the case of fair use, like on here, I think when I use your content, as an example, I should be required to give credit and/or be clear that you made it and I haven't, even if I never got permission.  Essentially, citing sources with each being easily found for those who are looking for them.  Of course, a direct re-post of your video on my channel should not be included, especially without permission.  In the case of that, I'd just compile a public playlist linking to the original video(s) to share their work.  To prevent false claims, I think both the accuser and accused should be required to provide sufficient evidence to support, or defend against, the claim which would be looked over manually by those working at YouTube, equivalent to showing their work.

This video is faulty because it seems to focus on how broken the copyright law is (which it is) and try to explain to people that the thing they are doing that they think is legal is in fact not. Almost the entire video is just "this thing you thought is legal, is not". Which is great and all. But does not make youtube system not actually broken. Because for all that many many instances of copyright infringement are legitimate. There are also many many examples where the copyright strike is not legitimate.
This video would be more accurately called "why many to most individual examples of youtube copyright system being broken is actually not youtube's fault but the law's fault". or even a "youtube's system is not broken in the way people think". But many examples does not an always make, and even if it did, there are some broken parts of the system.

The youtube system does not actually allow you to say "youtube, stop helping, I am taking them to court". instead youtube takes over for the courts and just steals the creator's money to give to the copyright claimant, or just removes all the content with no recourse.
This is not something required by law but something youtube decided to do on their own. Youtube system can be helpful to "a kid that accidentally infringed". but is not helpful for people who did not and actually want to sue the false claimant

Plus youtube has some really stupid arbitrary restrictions. an aggressor can issue an infinite number of a strikes but a defender can only defend against 3 at once. Again not a legal requirement but something youtube is doing just to screw the small guy

>Holliwood and big corps can't do that. maybe there should be different treatment between a kid on the internet and a big corp, but in current copyright law there is not.

This is actually factually untrue. countless examples of big corps stealing copyright and getting away with it.

What if instead of reducing copyright, we just added in provisions for independent creators. A universal 80/20 split for profits with the corporations getting the majority. Content ID could be used and expanded to cover not just videos and music but also images as well. Do away with the manual reporting, though, and place the burden on the companies to add their works into it. From where I stand as a former artist and YouTube creator, the parties want only one thing each. Artists want to be credited, companies want to make money, and creators want to create. Expanding Content ID and rewriting copyright law would please everyone. It would allow for artists to never be miscreated (and receive a portion of royalties from their label), it would allow for their labels and copyright owners to make their money, and it would allow content creators to share their projects while also providing a small financial incentive to take up the trade. You won't find millionaire creators anymore, but that's ok. It would still be enough to make a modest living doing it full time and every new creator that gets on board is another revenue stream for the copyright holders as well. Obviously there would have to be some limitations to prevent strait re-uploads or low-effort copying of works and, as it stands, it would only benefit YouTube in the short term as there would need to be other similar methods rolled out to other sites hosting copyrighted content but I do feel that everyone benefits from this. This way, copyright could last forever. No one would have to worry about items not being in the public domain cause the public domain would become obsolete. There would be no use for it when everyone is not only allowed to use copyrighted content in videos but also earn from them. I'm sure there are other legal issues that are entangled up in this solution and I'd love to debate those in the replies to this comment and find a way around them though.

As a retired software engineer, I cannot count the number of times I have had relatives, in-laws, and even my own spouse ask me what's wrong with copying a piece of software, after all, it's just a file / diskette / download. Well, I would reply, since that was how I made my living, that is tantamount to stealing. [Interestingly, this leads us to the real reason that, for several decades, software companies published huge paper manuals to go with disks -- to provide the end user with a sense of getting something for their money besides just a disk or two.] Copyright is there to protect all the work that goes into creating that thing of value that you wish to use for free -- don't do it! In IT we have Copyleft. Some licences permit any and all use, others require recontributing the modified code. This model has propelled our technological development and allowed you to upload free videos on youtube 14 years ago. There is still enough proprietary software around but this has also profited a lot from the open source community because there are a lot more capable developers who can showcase their code to employers. But Toooom, the same arguments you make about video gaming sales being affected by online streaming of gameplay could almost as easily be applied to someone going over to someone's house and watching them play it as well, thereby cutting sales in half (or more) if you (and possibly also others) watched the other person playing the game they bought, seeing the ending and deciding they didn't want it as a result...heck that argument of sales influence due to sharing of details without a sale involved in the share could even be applied to negative reviews with spoilers and detailed descriptions... What's the legality around trademarked names being featured and reviewed in blogs and on review websites etc.? 
.
The other thing is that lots of entitled small people who pull creations from bigger people (or perceived bigger people) and claim 'fair use' but who would be outraged if their clip was used by big companies without payment/credit, or who pinch fellow small folks' clips and yet wouldn't pinch big clips for fear of being expensively sued, is that the fear of being sued doesn't equate to conscience over copyright infringement: if that danger wasn't there they would do it without hesitation, and yet still expect credit/payment the other way round, because they believe that if someone can pay big bucks for a smaller person's creation then they should, but that people who wouldn't be able to pay to use creations not only shouldn't have to, but shouldn't be made to feel bad for not doing so. Until those people can be made to feel that small people ripping off each other or ripping off big people is as intrinsically unfair as big people ripping off small people, they won't have any conscience about trying to get away with ripping off what they can rip off without having to pay or credit creators. Even if they know that it's illegal, and even if they know WHY it isn't fair use. 
.
The real problem, I think, is a) envy on the part of people with ordinary income, of anyone or any company assumed to have made big money, and even a sense of communistic entitlement to a share of that big money, proportional to the perceived financial privilege gap between the big person and themselves, leading to resentment at perceived 'stinginess' and 'hoarding' if the big person insists on money/payment despite being perceived as having plenty of money relative to the person wanting to use their creations ("you have so much money thanks to us anyway - it's immoral to make your films so expensive to buy, so you have it coming to you and you deserve it"), b) believing that the big people can spare the money loss anyway, and it wouldn't even be a significant dent or scratch on their resources, so it's unreasonable of big people to ask small people for payment/credit for using their creations, c) that small people would never have made significant money from their creations anyway so what's the point in them 'aggressively' chasing payment/credit from other struggling small people for use of their creations, and d) a feeling that small people allowing unrestricted/unpaid/uncredited use of other small peoples' creations is simply bros supporting bros and therefore it's 'mean' to seek credit/payment from other small folk, and anyone who does deserves to be ripped off.
.
So the issue isn't just that copyright laws are misunderstood: it's that they're fought against by people who either genuinely believe they are justice crusaders fighting some kind of good fight in circumstances that are unjust and unfair through no fault of their own, or who convince themselves that this is the situation and that this is what they are doing, as smokescreens for their consciences. For some, if they aren't aware of the copyright law, then as soon as they are made aware, they still have no regrets, and indeed start looking for loopholes or ways to kick against those laws with everything in them. Until doing that feels wrong and bad to the majority of people, copyright law will always feel unfair and broken, and will always be resisted by some. People often claim to want equal rules for all people, but often when it comes it it, what's really wanted is lenience in favour of the poor (or self-perceived/comparatively poor) at the expense of the (too) rich (or perceived/comparatively too rich in the eyes of those people). Once that is understood, the psychology of copyright law resistance can be treated, and that's where the root of the problem really lies.

I know it's a bit more complicated than this but I've always been upset at copyright infringement regarding how they want their copyrighted material consumed. If someone has an edited film redone in a spoofed dub, and they're not making any money off of it, and it doesn't harm the original copyrighted material then what's the problem? It's like a company that makes shirts threatening legal action against people who bought shirts for wearing them on Sundays or wearing them at a political rally. The product has been "consumed" and whatever happens after this then the copyright holder should not have any control over it.

Also what will happen in the future, say in 200 years, when everyone has a relative who owns copyrighted material and so is watering down any significant financial gain from the copyright?

Great video!  A couple of comments:
1) The orphaned works problem is a real pity, _no_ _one_ benefits from that situation.  One
      class of proposed solutions that I like is to require copyright owners to pay a nominal
      fee or file a form perhaps every few years to keep a copyright in force.  If a work is in
      in active use, the copyright will be maintained.  If it is truly abandoned it will become public
2) Content ID is interesting.  This reminds me of patent pools, though not quite the same.
3) I agree that having a huge disconnect between the law and actual practise is an
    immense problem.  In effect, it gives enormous discretionary power to whoever has
    enough cash to hire tons of lawyers.  Not a good situation.  Regrettably, I doubt that this
    is going to get better during my lifetime.  The trend, in criminal law as well as IP law, has
    been in the opposite direction.
