Well, my job depends on copyright law and I understand it's needed to enable most business models of the creative industries, but ethically I'm not so sure it makes so much sense. 

I mean in a world without cheap, effortless copying you wouldn't really need copyright. If I want a Tesla model S, even if some other company made something really similar it wouldn't be the same. Even if they got all the schematics it might not be up to the same quality standards as the one produced by the people who've been involved in every step of the design of the vehicle. 
But if I write a song my business model consists in using the power of the State to restrict the freedom of everyone else to use that numerical sequence(frequencies and time intervals) that I came up with. People are not taking anything away from me(I still have the song even if someone else plays it, unlike stealing a physical object), in fact it is I who, by the act of coming up with that sequence, has stolen the right of everyone else to use it so I can charge money to return that freedom, with the power of the State backing me. If I live for 60 years after that, then that's 60 years of that State-backed monopoly on the usage of that sequence, plus 70 years where my descendants, who had absolutely no involvement in the creation of the sequence and who might be as creative as a rock, will still get the right to demand money to have access to the sequence. 

In any case I would get it if copyright where 10, 20 years at the most. It's plenty of time to take advantage of your exclusive rights to get money back for your effort. Then I think it's time to come up with something new, and let society build up on your ideas. 

Also, art not only existed but thrived for thousands of years before copyright law. Being able to create something once and then charge for access to reproductions is a relatively recent development. And it's a relatively small minority of creatives that gets to create something once and live ever after from it while most are still paid by the hour, the copyright being owned by their employers, so it's not like it's been a revolution for artists.

When YouTubers or others on the Internet use the phrase "no copyright infringement intended", it shows important one thing: They're confusing copyright infringement with plagiarism!


They've had it drilled into them by teachers in school for over a decade that you need to cite your sources, instead of presenting somebody else's ideas as their own.  They've been taught about plagiarism but until recent years nothing about copyright.  They think as long as they cite their sources, "Hey I got this from them! Your arguments regarding the term of copyright make me think that perhaps what is needed is essentially a new right that has a longer term. Call it "archival rights," maybe. Copyright lasts 20 years, and that's when you have full control over how a work is distributed and how much it costs to use it. Archival rights last 50 years, and entitle you to some flat fee (I'd set it around $100) when somebody uses your work without your permission. This recognizes the need for big budget artists to recoup their costs and build their brand, and the right of any caliber of artist to be rewarded for their contribution to culture, both without compromising on new artists' need to stand on the other guys' shoulders.

There's an alternative solution: Creative Commons (and copyleft more generally).  Instead of remixing the latest saccharine crap from Disney or shouty noise from [whichever rapster the kids are listening to this week], you can just use works licensed under terms that say "derivative works are allowed, but may only be distributed under this same licence".  And before you say "that couldn't possibly work", consider that _every image on Wikipedia_ (except for the handful of Public Domain ones) is used under a copyleft licence.


Of course, that means that you in turn can't demand royalties from other people using _your_ remix, which might suck if you're too unimaginative to think of any better method than bit-rent for making an income from your work.


Incidentally, if copyright were eternal, as you discuss at 33:25, then there wouldn't _be_ any Shakespeare to collect licence fees on, because Raphael Holinshed would have served the Bard a cease-and-desist.  (However, Luigi da Porto wouldn't have sued over _Romeo and Juliet,_ because Ovid's heirs would have sued _him_ for _Giulietta e Romeo_ being a blatant rip-off of _Pyramus and Thisbe._  Though Shakespeare might have gotten away with his use of _Pyramus and Thisbe_ in _Midsummer Night's Dream;_ it's parodic and at _least_ as transformative as MST3k.)

Japan, a country with one of the strictest copyright systems in the world, has a really curious case of blatant copyright infringement being overlooked. Doujinshi, or self-published works, are an entire industry there, widely known about and with many public events held and services set up for distribution of. While not all of it is necessarily using copyrighted content, a lot of it is. Manga, music, videogames and whatnot, often directly based on things that are still fresh off the presses, and yes, almost as often pornographic in nature, majority of them aren't in a gray zone, they are soot-black. Publishers have every legal (and occasionally moral too) right to shut all of that down... Yet they usually don't. They know that those are just works of passion, and despite being sold for money most can barely break even with printing costs and renting a stand, if that. It's also ample breeding ground for upcoming young artists, with many mangakas starting down there in the doujin scene.

I'm not sure that 50 years is all that much better than 95 years.  I mean at 95 years, its unlikely for someone who is alive when a work is produced will ever see that particular work move into the public domain, but at 50 years even if they'd see it they'll be in their 60s by the time stuff from their teens is released -- well beyond the average age of most Youtubers.  But that's maybe not the end of the world.  They can introduce their grandchildren to stuff from their youth and those grandchildren can make of it what they will.  Provides some level of generational transfer that 95 years may in some ways prohibit.

Life+75 for individuals is a bit nuts though.  Most artists peak between their mid-20s to mid-40s.  With an average age of ~80 years (rounded for ease,) that means 40-60 years of their life + 75 -- potentially 135 years of copyright.  And I'm not sure that its very legally clear what would happen if during year 134, the artist's great-great-great-great-grandchild sold the rights to a corporation.  Presumably since its defined as "publication+95" for corporations, it would automatically enter the public domain (being almost 40 years past that) but I imagine any such corporation would immediately claim that the original creation was not a "publication" (given that most individuals who retain their work for that long likely wouldn't have made it widely available to the public.)  So if they could successfully argue that (not that they're likely to need to -- very few works are even remembered never mind relevant 135 years later) then potentially the work could remain copyrighted for up to 229 years!  That's pushing 10 generations!

And that's assuming Disney doesn't get even more Mickey Mouse extensions pushed through during that time.

YouTube is broken. A few years ago, I used music with the right license. A company flagged the music as a copyright infringement. But the music they claimed was totally different. I got them to drop the case and say they made a mistake. But it means work for me for clearing a false claim. It was clearly a case of gross negligence in fact checking the claim. I wanted to fill a harassment complaint again the company to get their account closed. But YouTube refused to act. I could have sued in a local court (we have a law that nullifies the notion of choice of court). But it means wasting more time and money. In a proper system, the claim of harassment and false statement under oath should have placed the employee who filed the original claim under criminal charge and the company sued for liability. But to be realistic, there access to YouTube should have been terminated. I was not the only case with them. YouTube should add in their TOS a clause that a company filing a claim should pay 100$ each time where they get their money back only if the case is properly documented and proven. Doing that kind of shady business would get their access terminated for good and liable to pay the victim of the false claim.

So what if people start uploading their content, anonymously, to a decentralized network (there are already a few out there but I;m not sure how anonymous they are,  lbry is one such protocol).
On such networks it can be set that the users decide fair use. What can a company do (the network/protocol can also be set-up anonymously)?

If people move to such places in big numbers and it's set up to be completely anonymously then what would happen (money can still be made).
One important thing to note would be that it would not be in any country, is there truly an international law for this to begin with (since, Russia, China, North Korea, and many other countries might not adhere to your standard copyright law)?

Who are they even  going to  sue? Since once the protocol is out there, even the creators of the protocol might not be able to take it down (that's what a decentralized system does).

I think 50 years is a reasonable term for copyright *if* it allowed derivative works under compulsory licensing after 5 years. Basically, you'd retain the rights to the terms of your licensing for 5 years (when most of the money is made), but all creators would be allowed to use your work for a flat fee after that point. I'd rather it be something more like full-blown copyright for 2-5 years, followed by 15 years of CC-BY-NC-SA-ish licensing (plus compulsory licenses for commercial works), then 30 years with a CC-BY-NC-esque license and compulsory licensing for commercial works, followed by CC-BY for eternity. Attribution should be mandatory unless the creator explicitly waives their right to it or the author is unknown. I don't think Disney should still be making money from Pinocchio, but they do still deserve to be credited for it. But the Bible? We have no idea who actually deserves the credit, though I suppose the chapter and verse is good enough for attribution.


I also think that clips shorter than 10 seconds and screenshot-based memes should be legal, as long as credit is given and it isn't taken from the same work so much that you could string together clips and images to produce something near the original work.

When it comes to how much a law should be enforced there are two types of errors: under-enforcement and over-enforcement. The cost of over-enforcement is easily seen, which is why we hear about unjust take downs all the time. But the cost of under-enforcement is an unseen cost: it's all the movies and pictures and songs that have never been made because it's simply too hard to make money off of them when someone can just steal it consequence free. If you want to be serious about how the law should be or what YouTube should do about it, you have to take both of these problems into consideration, and not just focus on the examples that you read in the news.

In the interest of fixing the system it's trying to work around, copyright is a fix to work around the system of capitalism. People need money to survive, so under that system it makes sense that they should be able to get money from their work and have the rights to that work. But that system itself doesn't have to be the way the world works. People shouldn't have to have money to survive, that should just be a basic human right. Everyone should have the right to a decent life, it shouldn't have to be earned, you shouldn't have to work to survive, working under threat of death is in essence a form of normalized slavery, and I truly believe we have the resources to make that better world happen, if only corporate interests and propaganda weren't out to convince everyone a better world isn't possible so they can stay in power, with arbitrary ideas of some magical concept of unavoidable "human nature", the assertion that every other system is somehow even worse, the idea that someone can "earn" massive amounts of wealth as though they alone are responsible and the many workers that helped to make it happen aren't worth any more than minimum wage, all these ideas in the public consciousness to perfectly justify rich people and corporations being able to control the world while billions live in poverty and suffer. People shouldn't need to make money, and in a world where people don't need to make money, copyright doesn't need to exist. That's how you fix the underlying system.

Sure, copyright laws are not great but, that's not the issue here. People aren't mad over the law. They aren't mad because they think that YouTube is doing anything illegal with their copyright system even if they say otherwise. What they are actually mad at is the morality. The morality of the brutal power disparity between individual content producers and large companies wielding the law against them which in this case is actually YouTube's fault. YouTube and other companies like ride share companies like the ride sharing apps Lyft and Uber make their money by "employing" millions of people ("independent contractors") that produce their product (videos or transportation) without fair compensation.  I'm sure sometimes as a percentage of profit the pay is appropriate but that ignores the fact that by divorcing themselves of any sort of responsibility that traditional companies would have over their employees allows them to sell their products at a rate that would out-compete any competitor that tried to provide a similar service with even a modicum of employee support. The idea that YouTube is just an innocent bystander enforcing the law while benefiting immensely from the work of millions of people who they do not train or provide legal support for is wrong. YouTube's parent company Google (or I guess technically Alphabet) is one of the largest in the world and the only reason I can imagine that can't provide some level of support to the people that are it's bread winners is that it's fundamental structure is exploitative. So on the one hand they are at fault for not providing support if they can or on the other they cannot make money without exploiting people and should probably be closed down so another service that isn't fundamentally flawed can takes it's place.

There's one thing I'd like to add to the last section:
Mabye we want to move away from paying for art and towards paying people, that do art so they can make a living out of their craft without having to prevent others from remixing and redistributing their work. And there are solutions for that:
Open Lisences (more widely known as creative commons) and Plattforms like Patreon.


But those are basically just bodges as well trying to fix a broken system.

Open licences need to be more widely used and properly protected by law. Because you basically cannot put your work in the public domain even if you want to. You can say you've made it CC0, but when you actually read the fineprint on the creative commons page, you see ... CC0 is kind of in a legal grey area and it basically just works, because most have agreed to respect it.


We need to gain a better appreciation of this open art, we need to find better ways to support people, that want to do open art and we need to learn as a society: there are stories, that are incredibly important to tell ... but that simply won't get told because you wouldn't find a big enough audience to justify putting in the money to make those projects. But we still should find a way to make them happen and get the people paid, because of what that provides for our culture.

There's one simple thing that would fix a lot of problems with the false copyright strikes on Youtube. They shouldn't pay any ad revenue to any party before the appeal has been handled. Sure they could play the ads, but give the revenue retroactively to the one who ultimately wins the dispute. Regarding the expense of copyright litigation, take a look at the Akilah Hughes v. Carl Benjamin case.  Having won his motion to dismiss, Benjamin just filed a motion for fees. Nothing but the motion to dismiss, essentially.

Do you think YouTube could implement a revenue splitting system within content ID? 




I don't think you could do it based purely on how long the copyrighted content played for vs how long the video was _(not all part of the video are equally valuable),_ but in the case of a creator who accidentally use copyrighted material in music that only plays for a small portion of the video, even a 50/50 split is better than nothing.
(Edit)
I'm aware that there is a revenue split when there are multiple copyright claims on a single video; I'm talking about defaulting to letting the creator in on that split, except for in obvious(?) cases where they've just uploaded someone else's content.
i.e. In the case of a creator performing a cover, the creator might default to getting 50% of revenue for the performance, while the copyright holder gets the remainder for the composition copyright.
Definitely not a perfect system, but in the interim until we can get bet copyright law, it may work better than what YouTube does now.

I have a bone to pick about the concept of Fair Use with regard to the making of videos of video games however. I'll break it down based on the 4 main tenants of Fair Use that are seen, in my view. Of course this is not legal advice, but have been arguments brought up by the likes of the late Totalbiscuit in the past when it comes to this topic

1. The Transformative factor: Tom here in the video implies that the playthrough of an interactive medium does not amount to enough transformation if you are playing through similar scenes every/most players. I disagree on this point. While criticism or satire is covered under special protection under the transformative factor under fair use, your work does not need to purely critique or be a form of satire but rather "used to help create something new or merely copied verbatim into another work" (Measuring Fair Use: The Four Factors, Stanford University Libraries). Here, my argument is the additional element of entertainment provided by the creator through the medium of the video game in question. For example, I may not watch someone play through a horror video game for the video game itself, but rather the specific content creator in question being scared by situations in the video game. This additional layer of entertainment or enjoyment would be something I would never get through purely playing through the game alone, because there is likely no chance that my favourite content creator would be in front of me to scream from it. 


2. The Nature of the Copyrighted work: This is one factor that I'll admit I am not as familiar with this particular factor, it would be important to note that for most video games that require payment to access, one would usually not be able to attain access to the work unless payment is made, which is not necessarily through for the YouTube videos that come from it. I have not personally seen many cases flipped by this factor though

3. Amount and substantiality of the work used: This is the one factor that Ive seen more often than not weigh against streamers and/or lets play styled creators. Here it would be undeniable that a sizeable, sometimes all of the video game content would be used as a basis for content made by content creators, even if they cut out the cutscenes. The questionable part here would be whether the extent of content is necessary to create what is in my personal opinion, a transformative use of the game. Can a Let's Player realistically cut out major portions of gameplay that may or may not dictate idiosyncratic paths taken or subchoices made in how to approach a certain target or objective?

4. The Market Usurpation factor: This is where most of my concerns lie (along with the Transformative factor). Specifically, the notion of watching a content creator playthrough a video game amounts to a lost sale because of somehow drawing a parallel to have played the game yourself. For me, this would be a gross over-generalisation of what video games are, especially since the way you interact with a video/movie versus the way you interact through actually playing the game are markedly different factors. In most well-designed video games, you have the capacity to make different choices/approach missions in different manners with different setups, sometimes different from that taken by your favourite content creator. Personally, I would really budge against the notion of a limited interactivity media being a substitute for a full piece of differently interactive media. In my view, an argument can be made to separate and distinct the two markets, even if there may be people that are interested to be part of both markets: both for the video and for the video game.

Just my few cents, would be excited to see what others (or if Im lucky) Tom thinks xD

In terms of the morality behind the legality, the intent of copyright law is to encourage creativity. People are less likely to make things if they are unable to defend the profit they can receive from the thing they have made, and it is deemed morally correct that they have the ability to do so.
Conversely,  restricting the use of intellectual property blocks creativity. Michaelangelo, who made the famous David, perfected those skills in a career of mimicking ancient art. A more recent example can be seen in fan fiction, cover songs, and parodies of all kinds, many of which are as good as, if not better than, the original.
If the point of copyright law is to encourage creativity, then it may not only do so one way.

I think copyright should be 50 years or until death, whichever happens last. I'm a photographer, I think I should still own the pictures I take today when I retire. There's a fundamental difference between copyrights and patents in that patents can hold back development much further than copyright can. If I take photos or paint paintings in a new exciting style, they can still influence other artist even if I own the copyright. However If I invent something new and exciting no one else can do it, this is why you can't prevent someone from licencing a standard which you have patented. It's so you can't stop certain people from using eg. the network protocols required to do a specific task, you always have to licence it at a "reasonable price".

Copyright is meant to encourage people to make new works, however, those people coasting on the hit they made back in the 60s, or a book they published over fourty years ago haven't been producing new works otherwise they wouldn't be affected by a shortened copyright term. I do agree it needs to be shorted, but I definitely think it should be 20 years.

But false claims are still an issue, as are the mistakes of content id and lack of any reasonable way of youtubers especially the small ones of dealing with either, same goes for strikes for other transgressions based on completely unreasonable things, and there's no real way for youtubers to deal with those either , both often leading to channels, passion projects or even livelyhoods being deleted, locked down, or just threatened, but even that's not right and Youtube will more often than not just ignore it... It's impossible to say how significant these problems due to how big Youtube is and the massive shadow number that never gets any attention, but from what we have seen, this looks very bad for individual affected content creators to me. While it might usually be fine, sweeping those issues under the rug and saying that it should be fine, is actually bs.

Also about Content ID: I agree that for the most part, it's about as good as it can be under the current laws, but when claiming ad revenue from other people's videos and filing DMCA claims, the big firms have too much power and there is very little the small youtuber can do about it. Even if you appeal, by the time the revenue goes back to you, a good portion of the money that video will ever make is already gone. If the appeal goes through, any money claimed by then should be refunded. Also sometimes Game Developers strictly allow youtubers and streamers to post and stream videos using their game, but when you do something they don't like, like criticise the content a bit more harshly than they're used to, then they change their mind and file a DMCA, even though with criticism it would even be considered fair use.

Content ID may be a stopgap measure, but it certainly leaves a lot to be desired. It turns what is a transparent issue into an extremely opaque one with the added restrictions of 3 strikes and you're out. Such a system especially does not have benifit of a feedback loop that testing copyright in court has.

I have no doubt that even with changes in copyright law it is highly unlikely that youtube and it's media partners will wish to get rid of a system that can bypass the requirement of transparency and accountability.

As a comparison, github the world's largest code hosting site has far superior, albeit not perfect system. I'm sure many would agree that thr idea that youtube's internal copyright system isn't broken as well as our current copyright law is ridiculous.

I agree with this video.
In the past I have used an original song in the background of a video, that song was published by the original author under a Creative Commons licence. Many years later the video got claimed by some record label. I can only assume the artist had signed a deal with them. I responded with a copy of the licence that I held, as well as a hyperlink to where that media was still being distributed by the artist under that Creative Commons licence. However, I got an automated response threatening legal action. 

As mentioned in this video, I had no recourse because they have lawyers and I don't. I had a valid licence, and was able to prove it. Yet there was nothing I could do about it due to what I will assume was a lack of competence at said label. I would guess that the labels threats of suing were probably empty, since their main business proposition to artists was YouTube takedowns. 

But, I can't expect YouTube to die by the sword in moderating this. Since that could cause them huge legal liabilities.

Information should not be property. It became property because humans wanted to encourage creating information, and thus it had to be a sensible source of income. Under market liberalism that means it must be property.

We need a sensible way to encourage people creating information, and rewarding those creating the most liked and most important information, without making information property. That is what most people agree on: that artist should be rewarded, and that someone can't just claim their work as their own. Abstracting those aspects to intellectual property is just a fundamentally flawed way to solve the problem, yet it's required for capitalism to function.

Which means the question of copyrights isn't really a question about music, artist or corporations: it is a conflict between human nature and capitalism, and it showcases the difference between personal stuff you "own", and private property one owns.

A company does not have the capacity for independent thought, and therefore cannot create intellectual property, so how should it be able to own such a thing?

I can register my outro music at Distrokid, then claim my own video via their DMCA service. But equally hilarious, you can then sample the music or sound right before that, do the same at Distrokid, then claim my video as well. Then, if you're Time-Warner, you can bypass all of that and serve a DMCA from manual review with absolutely zero material from the complainant, re: Adam Neely's video claimed by Warner music for the section of the video playing JOYFUL NOISE not the section playing KATY PERRY even though Warner doesn't own Joyful Noise but YouTube just pushes the "Accept" button without bothering to investigate. 

The system doesn't use content id for most claims, it uses the honesty policy. They accept the claimants view without legal ramification even when the claimant admits at a later date that they claimed in bad faith, which IS illegal at least in the US. Filing in bad faith in the US courts has a precedent of going poorly for claimants. But not so when filling in the non-judicial YouTube court of corporate bureaucracy. 

Copyright law isn't the issue. Youtube didn't use copyright law. It uses "who is the largest corporation making a claim" law. Warner beats Distrokid beats you&me. No one beats Warner even when you win in court becayse you cost them 3 million while they false claimed 6 million in revenue. It's a net gain.

How to fix it, though? If Youtube wants to allow an algorithm to determine Fair Use or infringement, fine. But they accept the responsibility of adjudicating the appeals. That's the only change needed. Then suddenly they are liable for the bad faith claims. If they want to serve as an extra-judicial arbiter of revenue outside of the official courts, then it is only fair that they service all appeals.

Transformative critique: why _should_ a songwriter from the eighties still be able to profit from their song if a lifesaving patent from the 90's is no longer worth a dime? If anything, copyright law should last a lesser amount of time.

Additionally, the core problem with the current system is the burden of proof. I don't have to prove that you've violated copyright law in order to copyright strike your video. I only need the barest of an excuse. From a legal standpoint, that's backward. People are supposed to be innocent until proven guilty. If we enforced that standard, then companies probably wouldn't bother going after small channels, and peoples' behavior wouldn't need to change very much.

The bit on the copyrights for music failed to address one of the most infuriating parts of the YT ID system for classical fans, which is that Youtube often cannot tell the difference between a performance of a (well out of compositional copyright) classical piece that you performed and filmed yourself and thus own the rights to, versus the many professional recordings of the piece owned by UMG and Warner and EMI and whoever else, and will claim your performance as one of those recordings. This happens a lot more often than with covers of modern songs because a lot of classical pieces are written in a way that encourages fairly consistent performances, not putting your own spin on it the way cover artists like to - but each person's performance is still their own individual work, and YouTube's search-and-destroy bot is very bad at recognizing the little details that make them unique.

I am an illustrator. I know copyright is broken because since about 2005 I have not been able to retain copyright on any of my original work. Prior to that customers would pay me to make a custom artwork that they licensed for use in a particular work. However at some point lawyers decided that transfer of all rights would be boilerplate in every contract. So I do not, can not, retain rights to my own work in any sense. Theoretically putting my work in an online portfolio would be stealing from a major international publisher with many lawyers who could bankrupt me in minutes. This is not a symmetrical business relationship. I have no say in the terms dictated by the publisher.

Intellectual property rights have become a mechanism by which huge multi-national corporations collect all rights and honestly, as things stand, we would all be better off scrapping IPR and starting over than continuing as we have been.

I love your content Tom, but I don't know if its actually plausible to defend the stance that youtube's copyright system isn't broken.

Sure, the world's copyright system is flawed, but youtube actively allows deliberate copyright claim abuse because it is cheaper than defending its userbase.

Edit: 20 mins in, still think youtube's system is broken. Moreso, I feel like your argument about gaming videos being copyright infringement was interesting, but the delivery felt a bit aggressive. Yes of course according to the law it is copyrighted content, but it shouldnt be. You might not have bought those games you "substituted" by watching them on youtube, but it wasnt just you watching it. And be honest, you wouldnt have bought those games anyway. If you were planning to, you wouldnt have watched those videos. You probably wouldnt know of the games were they not to pop up for you in youtube. Untittled goose game wouldnt be nearly as popular as it is, and it wouldnt have sold nearly as much as it did, without content being created from the game.

So when the gaming community backlashes againts aggressive copyright claiming, wether it is lawful or not, it isnt because they are entittled and feel like they own the rights to the games, but because being able to stream and make videos of games is beneficial for literally everyone involved.

If you wanted to try a game before youtube, you would have to pirate it. Now you can just watch some gameplay a couple reviews and know wether you want to spend $60 on it. Now piracy is still very much a thing, but it mostly happens when piracy is a better service than the provider. So for example epic launcher exclusive games will be pirated because people want to avoid their launcher and boycott them, while the same people might have no issue shoving $60 into a game on steam. but lets not derail any longer.

The gaming community's major strenght is the community part. Gaming is the biggest entertaining industry and one of the reasons for this is the sharing of content. The experience of playing a game cant be simulated by watching a video of it. So for the most part gaming videos boost the sales of the games shown in a similar fashion to how piracy helps big studios through word of mouth. (Try not to pirate from small studios though, they dont benefit from it nearly as often as big ones do)

Do I think we should get rid of copyright laws? No. I can't imagine how tough it could be for an artist to not have some of these laws protecting their work. But we definitely need to define much more leeway into what is acceptable for a free to watch video or stream to show and profit from through ads, but not paywalls. (In this case it would make sense to define how many ads are acceptable for  a stream or video containing light use of copyrighted material, with considerations regarding what type of copyrighted content is being used.)

Reaction channels that just rip off other content and put a facecam on the side would still be infringing on copyright through this logic, but youtubers like you should be able to show an album cover without being affraid, amongst other things you weren't able to. Showing that album cover is not going to hurt its sales. if anything it might cause people to look the album up.

Few more minutes in, you actually give the argument to sustain the premise for your tittle. And it doesnt prove that youtube's content ID isn't broken. it just shows that it is arguably better than nothing.
Mind you Tom these are just my criticisms. Were I to attempt to praise all that I've liked about the video this comment would be 5 times longer, so please dont take this comment in a negative light. In the off chance that you read this I would love to hear some of your thoughts on what I have brought up. 

Thanks for the thoughtful, in depth videos you make.
Thank you for the amount of effort put into this video! It would be great to see reform, maybe the new generation will see it as important.
